newsitem.title: FRANCE: French planters want EU sugar regime maintained.
newsitem.headline: French planters want EU sugar regime maintained.

text.p: French sugar beet planters said on Thursday that there was no justification for changing the existing and largely self-financing EU sugar regime.

They also said they opposed recent calls for starting renegotiation of the 1994 GATT world trade pact ahead of schedule, namely at the World Trade Organisation ministerial meeting in Singapore on December 9-13.

"There is no need to renegotiate the farm side of the agreement before 1999. There is nothing to renegotiate in Singapore," CGB planters federation president Dominique Ducroquet told a news conference.
He said international farm trade negotiations could only start in the wake of the new reform of the Common Agricultural Policy scheduled for 1999.
The EU sugar sector was left virtually untouched by the GATT agreement that put curbs on subsidised exports. The current EU sugar regime is valid until end-June 2001.
But industry groups have said radical reforms are needed to bring the EU sugar sector into line with world trade rules.
Some have called for eliminating production quotas, reducing import tariffs and export subsidies and lowering sugar price levels.

Planters said the current system, which is largely self-financed, should be left unchanged. They said production quotas were necessary to insure a steady supply to national sugar production plants and that thriving world demand for food made curb on exports unnecessary.
They said large soft drinks companies were among those callling for lower EU sugar prices because they wanted to boost their profit margins.
But it was unlikely that a decline in sugar prices would benefit end-users, they said.
